docs.title: abstract
docs.text: A Java reserved word that serves as a modifier for classes, interfaces, and methods. An abstract class cannot be instantiated and is used to specify bodiless abstract methods that are given definitions by derived classes. Interfaces are inherently abstract.

docs.title: abstract class
docs.text: Same as abstract. A Java reserved word that serves as a modifier for classes, interfaces, and methods. An abstract class cannot be instantiated and is used to specify bodiless abstract methods that are given definitions by derived classes. Interfaces are inherently abstract.

docs.title: abstract data type (ADT)
docs.text: A collection of data and the operations that are defined on those data. An abstract data type might be implemented in a variety of ways, but the interface operations are consistent.

docs.title: abstract method
docs.text: Same as abstract. A Java reserved word that serves as a modifier for classes, interfaces, and methods. An abstract class cannot be instantiated and is used to specify bodiless abstract methods that are given definitions by derived classes. Interfaces are inherently abstract

docs.title: Abstract Windowing Toolkit (AWT)
docs.text: The package in the Java API (java.awt) that contains classes related to graphics and GUIs. See also Swing

docs.title: abstraction
docs.text: The concept of hiding details. If the right details are hidden at the right times, abstraction can significantly help control complexity and focus attention on appropriate issues.

docs.title: ADT
docs.text: abstract data type (ADT) - A collection of data and the operations that are defined on those data. An abstract data type might be implemented in a variety of ways, but the interface operations are consistent.

docs.title: aggregate object
docs.text: An object that contains variables that are references to other objects. See also has-a relationship.

docs.title: aggregation
docs.text: Something that is composed, at least in part, of other things. See also aggregate object.

docs.title: algorithm
docs.text: A step-by-step process for solving a problem. A program is based on one or more algorithms.

docs.title: alias
docs.text: A reference to an object that is currently also referred to by another reference. Each reference is an alias of the other.

docs.title: analog
docs.text: A representation that is in direct proportion to the source of the information. See also digital.

docs.title: animation
docs.text: A series of images or drawings that gives the appearance of movement when displayed in order at a particular speed.

docs.title: API
docs.text: Stands for application programming interface (API). A set of classes that defines services for a programmer. Not part of the language itself, but often relied on to perform even basic tasks. See also class library.

docs.title: applet
docs.text: A Java program that is linked into an HTML document and is then retrieved and executed using a Web browser, as opposed to a stand-alone Java application.

docs.title: appletviewer
docs.text: A software tool that interprets and displays Java applets through links in HTML documents. Part of the Java Development Kit.

docs.title: application
docs.text: (1) A generic term for any program. (2) A Java program that can be run without the use of a Web browser, as opposed to a Java applet.

docs.title: application programming interface (API)
docs.text: A set of classes that defines services for a programmer. Not part of the language itself, but often relied on to perform even basic tasks. See also class library.

docs.title: arc angle
docs.text: In the definition of an arc, the radial distance that defines the arc’s length. See also start angle.

docs.title: architectural design
docs.text: A high-level design that identifies the large portions of a software system and key data structures. See also detailed design.

docs.title: architecture
docs.text: Refers to computer architecture. The structure and interaction of the hardware components of a computer.

docs.title: architecture neutral
docs.text: Not specific to any particular hardware platform. Java code is considered architecture neutral because it is compiled into bytecode and then interpreted on any machine with a Java interpreter. See also bytecode.

docs.title: arithmetic operator
docs.text: An operator that performs a basic arithmetic computation, such as addition or multiplication.

docs.title: arithmetic promotion
docs.text: The act of promoting the type of a numeric operand to be consistent with the other operand.

docs.title: array
docs.text: A programming language construct used to store an ordered list of primitive values or objects. Each element in the array is referenced using a numeric index from '0' to 'N–1', where 'N' is the size of the array.

docs.title: array element
docs.text: A value or object that is stored in an array.

docs.title: array element type
docs.text: The type of the values or objects that are stored in an array.

docs.title: ASCII
docs.text: A popular character set used by many programming languages. ASCII stands for American Standard Code for Information Interchange. It is a subset of the Unicode character set, which is used by Java.

docs.title: assembly language
docs.text: A low-level language that uses mnemonics to represent program commands.

docs.title: assert
docs.text: A Java reserved word that is used to make an assertion that a condition is fulfilled. See also assertion.

docs.title: assertion
docs.text: A programming language construct that is used to declare a programmatic assumption (that is usually true). Assertions are used by JUnit for the purposes of unit testing. See also JUnit, unit testing.

docs.title: assignment conversion
docs.text: Some data types can be converted to another data type in an assignment statement. See widening conversion.

docs.title: assignment operator
docs.text: An operator that results in an assignment to a variable. The = operator performs basic assignment. Many other assignment operators, such as the *= operator, perform additional operations prior to the assignment.

docs.title: association
docs.text: A relationship between two classes in which one uses the other or is related to it in some way. See also operator association, use relationship.

docs.title: asymptotic complexity
docs.text: The order, or dominant term, of a growth function. See also dominant term, growth function.

docs.title: AWT
docs.text: Abstract Windowing Toolkit (AWT). The package in the Java API (java.awt) that contains classes related to graphics and GUIs. See also Swing.

docs.title: background color
docs.text: (1) The color of the background of a GUI component. (2) The color of the background of an HTML page. See also foreground color.

docs.title: bag
docs.text: A collection that facilitates the selection of random elements from a group. See also collection.

docs.title: Where And How To Learn C
docs.text:
Source https://www.reddit.com/r/C_Programming/comments/10zyicb/where_and_how_to_learn_c/

What resources did you use to learn C ? As a beginner to C, I'm finding it really difficult to pick up the language from just reading about the syntax rules. Are there any good resources / books / youtube videos to not only learn the syntax, but also the more advanced concepts (pointers, scope, etc)?

Edit: I know learning how to code takes time, but I'd prefer resources that wouldn't be so time consuming. More of a resource that I could approach when I'm stuck on a single topic

I've posted this here before and it's what has worked for me an a few others who told me it worked for them as well. Ymmv.

People sometimes struggle with C when they start from scratch or come from a higher to lower level of abstraction. I struggled with this for a long time till I did these things:

I would not try and understand how the higher level abstractions translate to the lower C level. I would instead learn from first principles on how a computer works and build the abstractions up from there. You will learn how a CPU works. How the data bus and registers are used. How memory is laid out and accessed. The call stack and how that works, etc.. This will go a long way in understanding how C sits on top of this and how it's data structures like arrays and structs map to this and understanding how pointers work the way they do and why. Check out these resources:

Read [Code: The Hidden Language of Computer Hardware and Software](http://charlespetzold.com/code)

Watch [Exploring How Computers Work](https://youtu.be/QZwneRb-zqA)

Watch all 41 videos of [A Crash Course in Computer Science](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL8dPuuaLjXtNlUrzyH5r6jN9ulIgZBpdo)

Take the [Build a Modern Computer from First Principles: From Nand to Tetris (Project-Centered Course)](https://www.coursera.org/learn/build-a-computer)

Take the [CS50: Introduction to Computer Science](https://online-learning.harvard.edu/course/cs50-introduction-computer-science) course.

Grab a copy of[ C programming: A Modern Approach](http://knking.com/books/c2/index.html) and use it as your main course on C.

Follow this [Tutorial On Pointers And Arrays In C](https://github.com/jflaherty/ptrtut13)

The first four really help by approaching C from a lower level of abstraction (actually the absolute lowest level and gradually adding layers of abstraction until you are at the C level which, by then is incredibly high!) You can do all four or pick one or two and dive deep. The 5th is a great introduction to computer science with a decent amount of C programming. The sixth is just the best tutorial on C. By far. The seventh is a deep dive into pointers and one of best tutorial on pointers and arrays out there (caveat, it's a little loose with the l-value/r-value definition for simplicity sake I believe.)

https://github.com/practical-tutorials/project-based-learning#cc

Play the long game when learning to code.

You can also check out Teach Yourself Computer Science

Here is a decent list of 8 Books on Algorithms and Data Structures For All Levels

I agree with this. Nand2Tetris is especially very good for foundational knowledge. I also recommend reading Computer Systems: A Programmer's Perspective. You can also watch the video lectures from the authors of CS:APP : https://www.cs.cmu.edu/afs/cs/academic/class/15213-f15/www/

Started learning mid-summer last year and would recommend using more than one tool to learn, and make one of those a book. Here is a video series I came across that was clearly presented and easy to follow:

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLBlnK6fEyqRhX6r2uhhlubuF5QextdCSM .

Also, I think you will find some useful info in some of these post. Scan for relavent post titles: https://www.reddit.com/r/C_Programming/search/?q=learn%20book&restrict_sr=1&sr_nsfw=&include_over_18=1

un through basic syntax for free on learn-c.org.

Start solving real problems quickly with https://www.codestepbystep.com/problem/list/c

If you are not adverse to learning from books, get The C Programming Language 2nd Edition, it gives you little examples and tasks to explore in every chapter.

Whenever you do anything to learn, never copy-paste. Always type the code in your own editor. This helps you build knowledge of syntax and constructs.

This online book helped me more than anything else:

https://beej.us/guide/bgc/

I was scanning through the replies to see if anyone else had already mentioned this book. I've been using it as a supplement to one of my classes where we need to learn a bit of C, and have found the book to be incredibly clear and quite helpful. The writing style, which maintains an easygoing sort of tone, helps keep the material approachable.

It may be worth noting that there are two volumes to the guide, a tutorial and a reference. I didn't see that right away, as the reference is only mentioned briefly in a link towards the top of the page, with the actual download being on the linked page. As someone new to C and programming in general, it's helpful to have a reference guide for common functions written in a relatively approachable language, as I can sometimes become a bit lost in the jargon of official documentation meant for a more professional audience.

In fact, in a moment of procrastination, I was just looking at the Dedication section of the book. Beej specifically thanks the users of r/C_programming. Hence, my arrival in this sub a few minutes ago. Who knows, maybe Beej will see this post too.

docs.title: Enhanced For Loops
docs.text:
The usual way to step through all the elements of an array in order is with a "standard" for loop, for example,

for (int i = 0; i < myArray.length; i++) {
    System.out.println(myArray[i]);
}

The so-called enhanced for loop is a simpler way to do this same thing. (The colon in the syntax can be read as "in.")

for (int myValue : myArray) {
    System.out.println(myValue);
}

The enhanced for loop was introduced in Java 5 as a simpler way to iterate through all the elements of a Collection (Collections are not covered in these pages). It can also be used for arrays, as in the above example, but this is not the original purpose.

Enhanced for loops are simple but inflexible. They can be used when you wish to step through the elements of the array in first-to-last order, and you do not need to know the index of the current element. In all other cases, the "standard" for loop should be preferred.

Two additional statement types, break and continue, can also control the behavior of enhanced for loops.

Source: https://www.cis.upenn.edu/~matuszek/General/JavaSyntax/enhanced-for-loops.html

Other examples... The Java ternary operator examples | alvinalexander.com

docs.title: Enhanced If Statements (Short Form If Statements) Ternary Operator Examples
if-then-else
docs.text:
I'm always forgeting how to use the ?: ternary operator. This supplemental answer is a quick reminder. It is shorthand for if-then-else.

myVariable = (testCondition) ? someValue : anotherValue;

where

  • () holds the if
  • ? means then
  • : means else

It is the same as

if (testCondition) {
    myVariable = someValue;
} else {
    myVariable = anotherValue;
}

docs.title: if, else if, else
docs.text:
You can write if, else if, else statements in short form. For example:

Boolean isCapital = city.isCapital(); //Object Boolean (not boolean)
String isCapitalName = isCapital == null ? "" : isCapital ? "Capital" : "City";

This is short form of:

Boolean isCapital = city.isCapital();
String isCapitalName;
if(isCapital == null) {
    isCapitalName = "";
} else if(isCapital) {
    isCapitalName = "Capital";
} else {
    isCapitalName = "City";
}

Source: Short form for Java if statement - Stack Overflow

Other Examples... The Java ternary operator examples / alvinalexander.com
